awd_abstract_narration:
Symmetries, which can be mathematically described by groups, play an important role in science. In quantum physics, the fundamental theory of physics at small scales, operator algebras provide a mathematical framework to study quantum systems and their symmetries. To describe quantum particles and matter in low dimensions (for example, on a thin layer) one needs a generalization of symmetry that goes beyond groups, often referred to as quantum symmetries. A main focus of this project is to find models realizing such symmetries in quantum field theory, which combines the principles of quantum physics and the theory of special relativity. The goal is to use the rich interplay between operator algebras and quantum field theory via conformal nets and to better understand possible quantum symmetries in mathematics and low-dimensional physics. One potential application is topological quantum computing, where the goal is to use quantum operations coming from non-trivial quantum symmetries to perform computations.

Conformal nets give rise to interesting quantum symmetries in terms of subfactors and unitary modular tensor categories. The project will focus on three main directions. First, the principal investigator will extend the understanding of boundaries or defects between conformal nets, generalize the abstract description of defects in terms of braided subfactors, and explore the relation to Jones' planar algebras. The second project focus is to provide new structural results and examples of rational conformal nets realizing the quantum doubles subfactors. Lastly, the principal investigator will develop methods for using operator-algebraic techniques to construct conformal nets from their quantum symmetries and give relations between the operator algebraic approach of conformal nets and the purely algebraic approach of vertex operator algebras.

por.por_cntn:
Symmetries, which can be mathematically described by groups, play an important role in science. In quantum physics, the fundamental theory of physics at small scales, operator algebras provide a mathematical framework to study quantum systems and their symmetries. To describe quantum particles and matter in low dimensions (for example, on a thin layer) one needs a generalization of symmetry that goes beyond groups, often referred to as quantum symmetries. As a main outcome of this project we describe quantum symmetries in quantum field theory, which combines the principles of quantum physics and the theory of special relativity. In particular, we describe generalized symmetries given by compact hypergroups that generalize well-studied symmetries of compact groups. 


Conformal nets give rise to interesting quantum symmetries in terms of subfactors and unitary modular tensor categories. In this project we  extend the understanding of boundaries or defects between conformal nets, generalize the abstract description of defects in terms of braided subfactors. Those defects are believed to form so-called multifusion categories and we classify on the action of such categories on a certain class of von Neuman algebras. We provided new structural results and examples of rational conformal nets realizing the quantum doubles subfactors and realization of a family of unitary modular tensor categories, the so-called Tambara-Yamagami Categories. Lastly, using operator-algebraic techniques we give a general Galois theory for discrete inclusions of conformal nets given by compact hypergroups that generalizes the symmetry given by compact groups. In this context, we give a notion of quantum operations on conformal nets and show that conformal subnets are characterized by all quantum operations fixing the subnet.
